title: Add 'command' voice command with Claude Code chat panel
description:
## What This Feature Is

You want to **talk to Claude Code through VoiceFlow**. Not dictation - actual delegation. You speak, Claude acts.

Right now VoiceFlow is a **transcription tool** - it turns your voice into keystrokes in whatever app you're focused on. This new feature makes it a **command interface** to an AI agent that can actually do things on your behalf.

---

## The Two Modes

### Mode 1: "command [whatever]" - Fire and Forget

```
You: "command write down that I should call Mom tomorrow"
     ‚Üì
Claude Code executes in background
     ‚Üì
Brief response appears somehow (TBD)
     ‚Üì
You continue what you were doing
```

### Mode 2: "command open" - Interactive Session

```
You: "command open"
     ‚Üì
Chat panel appears
     ‚Üì
You type/talk back and forth with Claude
     ‚Üì
Full conversation with tool output visible
     ‚Üì
"command close" or Escape to dismiss
```

---

## Why ~/ai-os?

This isn't a generic Claude instance. It's **your** Claude - the one in ai-os with:
- Your MCP servers (email, calendar, memory, etc.)
- Your CLAUDE.md instructions
- Your tool configurations
- `--dangerously-skip-permissions` so it can actually act

The working directory indicator reminds you this is the "real" Claude with full capabilities.

---

## The Panel When Open

A **second floating window** (separate from the transcript panel) that's basically a lightweight chat client:

```
‚îå‚îÄ Command Panel ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ üìÅ ~/ai-os                    [√ó]       ‚îÇ  ‚Üê Working dir indicator
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§
‚îÇ                                         ‚îÇ
‚îÇ You: Check my email                     ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                                         ‚îÇ
‚îÇ Claude: You have 3 unread emails...     ‚îÇ
‚îÇ   ‚ñ∂ Tool: mcp_gmail_search [collapsed]  ‚îÇ  ‚Üê Expandable tool use
‚îÇ   ‚ñ∂ Tool: mcp_gmail_read [collapsed]    ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                                         ‚îÇ
‚îÇ You: Reply to the one from Sarah        ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                                         ‚îÇ
‚îÇ Claude: Done. I sent: "Thanks Sarah..." ‚îÇ
‚îÇ   ‚ñ∂ Tool: mcp_gmail_send [collapsed]    ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                                         ‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§
‚îÇ [Type a message...]            [Send]   ‚îÇ  ‚Üê Input at bottom
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
```

### Key Properties
- **Non-activating** - doesn't steal focus from your current app
- **Lightweight Swift feel** - not a web view, native and fast
- **Collapsible tool output** - see what Claude did without clutter
- **Message queue** - can type ahead while waiting for response

---

## The Inline Response Question (Undecided)

When you say "command xyz" without opening the panel, where does the response go?

### Option C - Overlay on Existing Transcript Panel
- Response appears as a card in/on the VoiceFlow panel
- Has "Open Full" button if you want more
- Dismiss to clear

### Option E - Smart Routing
- Short responses ‚Üí toast notification
- Long responses ‚Üí auto-open the full panel
- More adaptive, less predictable

---

## Primary Use Cases

1. **"command check my email and tell me what's important"**
   - Claude searches gmail, summarizes
   - You get a quick answer

2. **"command write down [idea] and add it to my memory"**
   - Claude writes to your memory system
   - Brief confirmation: "Added to memory"

3. **"command what's on my calendar today"**
   - Claude checks calendar MCP
   - Lists your meetings

4. **"command open"** ‚Üí then interactive conversation
   - For anything multi-turn
   - For when you want to see the details

---

## What This Enables

You're building **voice-first AI assistance**. The pattern is:

1. You're doing something (coding, writing, browsing)
2. You have a thought or need
3. You say "command [thing]"
4. It happens
5. You continue what you were doing

**No context switching. No opening apps. No typing. Just speak and it's done.**

---

## Technical Approach

### Voice Commands
- **'command open'** - Opens the command panel for interactive chat
- **'command close'** - Closes the command panel (Escape key also closes)
- **'command [text]'** - Executes [text] as immediate command (inline mode)

### New Files to Create
1. `CommandPanelWindow.swift` - NSPanel subclass (similar to FloatingPanelWindow)
2. `CommandPanelView.swift` - SwiftUI chat interface
3. `ClaudeCodeService.swift` - Process management and stdio communication
4. `CommandMessage.swift` - Model for chat messages
5. `CommandResponseOverlay.swift` - (if Option C) overlay view for inline responses

### AppState Changes
- `isCommandPanelVisible: Bool`
- `commandMessages: [CommandMessage]`
- `commandPendingInput: String`
- `claudeCodeService: ClaudeCodeService?`
- `inlineCommandResponse: CommandMessage?` (for inline mode)

### Claude Code Integration
- Spawn process: `claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --output-format stream-json`
- Working directory: ~/ai-os
- Pipe stdin for messages, parse stdout for streaming responses
- Process persists across commands within session

---

## Out of Scope (v1)
- Voice input directly to command panel (uses keyboard for now)
- Multiple concurrent sessions
- Persistent conversation history across app restarts

title: Architecture: Hybrid App Store + Direct Distribution Strategy
description:
Design VoiceFlow with modular architecture to support both App Store (lite) and direct distribution (pro) versions.

## Background
- Accessibility API (AXUIElement) required for context-aware features
- Accessibility API NOT allowed in Mac App Store sandbox
- Input Monitoring (CGEventTap) IS allowed in sandbox

## Strategy
**App Store Lite Version:**
- Basic dictation (type at cursor)
- Voice commands
- Uses Input Monitoring only

**Direct Pro Version:**
- All lite features plus:
- Context-aware punctuation (reads text field content)
- Smart terminal mode detection
- Inline text rewriting/replacement

## Implementation Notes
- Core engine should be shared between versions
- Accessibility features should be modular/optional
- Runtime detection of available permissions
- Feature flags or build configurations to differentiate

title: Add 'long command' keyword for extended voice commands
description:
## Overview

Add special keywords for capturing longer voice commands that may contain natural pauses.

## Problem

Currently 'command [text]' requires the text to be spoken in one breath/utterance. For longer commands like 'command check my email and summarize the important ones and then write a response to Sarah', natural pauses might cause early termination.

## Proposed Keywords

### Option 1: Explicit Stop Keyword
- **'long command [text] stop listening'** - Captures everything between 'long command' and 'stop listening'
- Example: 'long command check my email [pause] summarize what's important [pause] and draft a response to Sarah stop listening'

### Option 2: Extended Pause Mode  
- **'long command [text]'** - Uses much longer pause threshold (e.g., 3-5 seconds) before finalizing
- Natural pauses allowed, only very long silence ends the command

### Option 3: Both
- 'long command' uses extended pause
- 'stop listening' can be used to end early if desired

## Technical Approach

Similar to how 'say' enters literal mode, 'long command' would:
1. Enter a special capture mode
2. Buffer all speech (skip command matching for content)
3. Wait for stop keyword OR extended silence
4. Send entire captured text to Claude Code

## Related

This is part of the command-agent voice mode feature set (VoiceFlow-06v).

title: Save raw audio recordings with dictation history
description:
Save the raw audio recordings alongside transcription history for:
- Playback/review of what was actually said
- Debugging transcription issues
- Training/fine-tuning local models
- Accessibility review

## When to Record
- **Only when mic is "hot"**: On mode or Push-to-Talk active
- **NOT in Sleep mode**: Don't save audio while waiting for wake word
- This significantly reduces storage and privacy concerns

## Implementation Ideas
- Save audio chunks to disk during capture (PCM/WAV format)
- Link audio files to transcript entries in history
- Add playback button in history view
- Configurable retention period (auto-delete old recordings)
- Storage location setting (default ~/Library/Application Support/VoiceFlow/recordings/)

## Considerations
- Storage space (16kHz mono PCM is ~1.9MB/minute)
- Privacy implications - clear user consent
- Option to disable recording entirely
- Compression options (AAC, FLAC, Opus)

title: App stops transferring text to target window after running for a while
description:
After some time running, VoiceFlow stops typing text into the target window. Speech recognition may still work (text appears in panel) but keystrokes aren't being sent.

**Workaround**: Saying 'speech off' then 'speech on' fixes it - cycling the mode resets stuck state.

Possible causes:
1. typedFinalWordCount getting out of sync with actual typed words
2. lastTypedTurnOrder stuck at wrong value
3. didTypeDictationThisUtterance not resetting properly
4. WebSocket state issues

The mode cycle triggers resetUtteranceState() which likely clears the stuck state.

### macOS 26 SpeechAnalyzer (Now Available)
- 2.2x faster than Whisper V3 Turbo
- On-device, no rate limits
- Modules: SpeechDetector, SpeechTranscriber, DictationTranscriber

### Recommended Architecture
1. Porcupine/openWakeWord for always-on wake (<4% CPU)
2. Apple SpeechTranscriber for commands
3. AssemblyAI for high-accuracy dictation

### Sources
- picovoice.ai/platform/porcupine
- github.com/dscripka/openWakeWord
- developer.apple.com/documentation/speech/speechanalyzer

title: Evaluate wake word alternatives - 'flow' is hard to recognize
description:
The 'flow' prefix commands (flow on, flow off, flow sleep) use the /f/ sound which is a weak labiodental fricative. Research indicates:

- /f/ is harder to detect than plosives (k, t, p) or sibilants (s)
- Recommended wake words have 6+ phonemes; 'flow on' only has ~5

Consider alternatives with stronger starting sounds:
- 'voice on/off/sleep' (voiced fricative, 6 phonemes)

When utterances combine mode commands with "say" escape:
- "speech on say press enter" ‚Üí "say" is not at start ‚Üí escape fails
- "say press enter" (alone) ‚Üí works correctly

The issue is "say" must be at transcript START to trigger escape.

## Fix Needed

After stripping wake/mode commands from the transcript beginning, check if the REMAINING text starts with "say" and treat it as literal.

Example flow:
1. "speech on say press enter" arrives
2. "speech on" is detected and processed as mode switch
3. Remaining "say press enter" should be checked for "say" prefix
4. If found, escape the rest ("press enter" ‚Üí literal text)

title: Add FluidAudio Parakeet as offline ASR option
description:
## Research Summary

NVIDIA's Parakeet ASR models can run on-device via **FluidAudio** (Swift package that converts them to CoreML for Apple Neural Engine).

### Available Models via FluidAudio

| Model | Size | Languages | Best For |
|-------|------|-----------|----------|
| parakeet-eou-160 | ~250MB | English | Streaming with EOU detection (lowest latency) |
| parakeet-tdt-0.6b-v2 | ~600MB | English | Highest English accuracy (6.05% WER) |
| parakeet-tdt-0.6b-v3 | ~600MB | 25 languages | Multilingual support |

### Reference Implementation

Yappatron already uses FluidAudio's Parakeet EOU 120M model - see `/Users/jacobcole/code/yappatron/packages/app/Yappatron/Sources/TranscriptionEngine.swift` for working code.

Key components:
- `StreamingEouAsrManager` - handles streaming ASR with end-of-utterance detection
- 160ms audio chunks for low latency
- Configurable EOU debounce (silence threshold)
- Partial + final transcription callbacks
- 16kHz mono Float32 audio format

### Integration Approach

1. Add FluidAudio SPM dependency: `https://github.com/FluidInference/FluidAudio.git`
2. Create `FluidAudioService.swift` following the existing service pattern (like AppleSpeechService)
3. Add `DictationProvider.fluidAudio` or `.parakeet` enum case
4. Wire up audio capture (already 16kHz mono in AudioCaptureManager - may need Float32 conversion)
5. Add model download on first use (via `DownloadUtils.loadModels`)

### Considerations

- Models are CC-BY-4.0 licensed (commercial use OK)
- ~250-600MB download on first use
- Requires macOS 14.0+ / iOS 17.0+
- Uses Neural Engine (power efficient)
- Potentially better accuracy than Apple Speech for dictation

### Sources
- https://github.com/FluidInference/FluidAudio
- https://huggingface.co/nvidia/parakeet-tdt-0.6b-v3
- https://developer.nvidia.com/blog/pushing-the-boundaries-of-speech-recognition-with-nemo-parakeet-asr-models/

## Verification Needed

### Test Cases

1. Enable "Live Dictation" mode in settings
2. Use Apple Speech (offline mode)
3. Speak a sentence and verify no punctuation is added
4. Test with online providers (AssemblyAI/Deepgram) - document behavior

### Potential Issues

- AssemblyAI's `format_turns` setting (ticket VoiceFlow-s7l) may need to be exposed

- Need to verify AI formatter doesn't re-add punctuation when no-punctuation mode is active

title: Add processing indicator for PTT waiting state
description:
When PTT is released, there's now a brief period where the app waits for finalized text before going to sleep. Users have no visual indication that text is still being processed and will appear shortly.

## User Need
User should know that if they wait just a bit longer, finalized text will appear. Currently the UI gives no hint that processing is happening.

## Preferred Option: Vibrating Waveform Animation üéµ

User prefers a **bouncing/vibrating waveform** style indicator - like audio processing bars that pulse up and down.

### Implementation Approach

```swift
// Bouncing bars with staggered animation
struct ProcessingWaveView: View {
    @State private var animate = false
    let barCount = 4
    
    var body: some View {
        HStack(spacing: 2) {
            ForEach(0..<barCount, id: \.self) { i in
                RoundedRectangle(cornerRadius: 1)
                    .fill(Color.accentColor)
                    .frame(width: 3, height: animate ? 12 : 4)
                    .animation(
                        .easeInOut(duration: 0.4)
                        .repeatForever()
                        .delay(Double(i) * 0.1),
                        value: animate
                    )
            }
        }
        .onAppear { animate = true }
    }
}
```

### SwiftUI Resources
- SwiftfulLoadingIndicators: https://github.com/SwiftfulThinking/SwiftfulLoadingIndicators
- WavingAnimationView: https://github.com/guledaaydemir/SwiftUI-Animations  
- Hacking with Swift WaveView: https://www.hackingwithswift.com/plus/custom-swiftui-components/creating-a-waveview-to-draw-smooth-waveforms

## Other UI Options Considered

### Option 1: Animated Microphone Icon
- Pulse or spin animation on the mic icon while waiting for finalized text

### Option 2: Small Processing Spinner
- Add a small circular spinner next to the transcript area

### Option 3: Text Shimmer/Skeleton
- Show a subtle shimmer on the last word(s) of transcript

### Option 4: Status Text
- Show "Processing..." or "..." in transcript area

## Implementation Notes
The `pendingPTTSleep` flag in AppState already tracks this state. Could expose it as a @Published property to drive UI updates.
